abstract.p: This is an open cover letter to apply for the position of User Experience Researcher at Mozilla. First, I explain my motivations on how I feel that Mozilla will fullfil my career. Second, I describe how my values can serve Mozilla. Third, I sketch some ideas for future work that we can make together.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Calling this webpage Magicians of Moz is a bold move. I adore puns. I always name my projects with 1-to-3-word aliases to make them easier to remember and talk about, like bookmarks. There are several main ideas contained in Magicians of Moz:

1) Arthur Clarke's third law (spotted through a recent reminder) says: Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic. This directly applies to the field of Human Computer Interaction (HCI). This can be applied to other fields from art, science and technology. For instance, sound design in a movie becomes great once it is not noticeable anymore. Technology should serve users and achieve it through the best transparency.

2) A traditional usability engineering technique has been named after the famous novel and movie The Wizard of Oz. It allows to evaluate systems with users even when these systems are not yet functional. Human evaluators replicate the desired functionalities. A similar train of thoughts may lead us to the Mechanical Turk. Amazon's version may be employed for remote user testing, but does raise societal issues. The term Magician is also gender-neutral (as opposed to for instance Wizard). Systems and tools should be designed for users and the user-centered design process should be respectful of the people involved.

3) This is an open cover letter for applying as User Experience Researcher at Mozilla. There are already lots of magicians at Mozilla, I could discuss with some of them. My passion gets attracted by the Mozilla UX and MozVR teams who prototype and evaluate with users novel ways of browsing the Internet. The plural in Magicians means that I want to be part of them. This cover letter, online and open, follows up the new tradition established by one of the Mozillians.

Usually a cover letter may address three main parts: 1) what is being sent and why, 2) who the sender is, and 3) what the sender can make together with the recipient organization. Consider the first part done. I will slightly adapt the two remaining sections. First, I will explain my motivations on how I feel that Mozilla will fullfil my career. Second, I will describe how my values can serve Mozilla. Third, I will sketch some ideas for future work that we can make together.

sec.title: Why Mozilla? A user's standpoint.
sec.p: I use Mozilla products. Really. I have been relying on Firefox and Thunderbird for a decade. I prefer not to be traced when browsing the Internet and I want to be free to switch anytime between the major desktop platforms. I would love to use Firefox OS once it runs on a responsible phone. Sorry, I have not yet contributed to any of these three major products so far. However, I use projects powered by Mozilla technologies or Firefox extensions, and contribute to some: Paper Machines for visual text analytics in bibliography manager Zotero, GUI prototyping tool Pencil for sketching diagrams and ideas. So I have already been attracted to Mozilla first as a user. What could be better than being hired to improve one's favorite tools? But wait, there is a catch. As Jennifer Morrow wrote on her last post before her departure from Mozilla UX: Scratch-your-own-itch hacker culture assumes the creators of technology are its users, which deemphasizes the need for usability and accessibility.

sec.title: Why Mozilla? A researcher's perspective.
sec.p: Beyond being a user, the third word in the position title is researcher. From my experience in academia I have learned that scientific researchers question issues, try to create or improve solutions to solve these, and document their findings ideally on publications. Speaking of publications, let's assume we want to first trace all scientific publications authored by direct members of Mozilla (including the staff from Mozilla Science Lab would make it harder). This cover letter may be more similar to a position paper than to a scientific article, thus a proper systematic literature overview can be considered off-topic. To get an estimate, we can search the ACM Digital Library first for publications whose authors are affiliated to Mozilla. The query can be defined as follows: persons.authors.affiliation:(+mozilla). This leads us to 40 results.

Among these results, how many are related to user experience? Instead of enforcing keywords such as user experience or usability onto the search, I propose to first collect some clues elsewhere. On the Mozilla Research blog, posts can currently belong to the following categories: Emscripten, Events, Rust, Servo, Shumway, Uncategorized. Most of these are web-based multimedia technologies. To narrow down results to publications concerning user experience, I thus propose to filter web technologies and programming languages employed at Mozilla from the title and abstract and multimedia from the publication source title. The query can then be refined as follows: persons.authors.affiliation:(+mozilla) AND recordAbstract:(-javascript -rust -c++ -java -html -http -python -language -Emscripten -Rust -Servo -Shumway) AND acmdlTitle:(-javascript -rust -c++ -java -html -http -python -language -Emscripten -Rust -Servo -Shumway) AND acmdlPublicationTitle:(-*multimedia). This leads us to 8 results: 2 tutorials (OpenSym14, SIGCSE'14), 2 workshops (RELENG'13, RELENG'15, more related to quality assurance), 1 long paper (CSCW'13), 1 keynote (SPLASH'13), 1 panel (CHI'09), 1 artistic demo (SA'12).

One first finding from this literature overview from Mozilla authors related to user experience research is that both the variety of presentation types and the variety of affiliations among co-authors may incline to think that Mozilla researchers are open to discuss their practices and collaborate with academic and industrial partners. As a potential Mozilla UX researcher, I would enjoy collaborating with academic/industrial peers and publishing research results with the UX team.

sec.title: Why Mozilla UX? A user researcher passion.
sec.p: On a recent website, people from the Firefox UX team outline their design process and values that have been elaborated for years. One quite attractive figure illustrates their Design Process. There are five phases: 1) Conduct research on human needs and behavior. 2) Create concepts by blending research findings, technological insights and Mozilla mission values. 3) Iterate on design by prototyping, testing and refining. 4) Build and ship. 5) Measure with people. Address issues from the core before prototypes are made. I have been following an iterative process very similar phases for my research on HCI through engineering and usability. I would like to remain actively involved on all these phases, shall I become a member of the Firefox UX team.

On the same website, people from the Firefox UX team also define their Design Values. One key advantage from the chosen visualization as a donut chart is that user experience researchers can use it as a framework to analyze a research process, and display, by sizing the areas of each value accordingly to their completeness, how the process fits the framework. I will continue by explaining how our values can relate.

sec.title: Values
sec.p: My code of conduct and criteria for a good career as user experience researcher can be organized as follows:

sec.title: Work driven by passion and emotion
sec.p: Art installationWeburette from Akatsuka Daisuke (Mozilla Japan), cited here before, transduces the flow of processes issued when loading a web page into liquids, mapping information (networking, building the DOM, number of links, local storage, visited links, garbage collection) to different fluids. Visuals are available on his collaborator Tomoki Hiramoto's Behance gallery. Past the information display, this installation directly fascinates and triggers emotion. It makes me recall amused reactions of people discovering LavaAMP, an installation that Eric Schayes and I created that is quite similar since it browses music through liquids, it surrounds the beats in music tracks by streaming colorful blobs. This was one of my best experience of designing a system: the chills for creating it, and the satisfaction seen on people discovering it. But wait, were people really satisfied? This would require proper evaluation methods.

sec.title: Evaluate ideas and prototypes with people
sec.p: My Myers-Briggs Type of personality Indicator (MBTI) is Introvert iNtuitive Feeling Perceiving (INFP), which confirms that I can be very empathetic to people and a good listener. This trait of personality helped me run contextual inquiries, particularly as 1:1 interviews. Trained in an engineering environment, I am also accustomed to making surveys, mostly for feedback after user testing and evaluation, from my PhD thesis. I always make sure to formulate questions in surveys so that answers can be analyzed quantitatively. Throughout the Auracle project I have also learned how to measure where and how people look with eye tracking. I find that Alex Wright's rendering of the space for UX methods shown during his workshop Humanizing data outlines well usability methods by positioning these on two axes: attitudinal-behavioral and qualitative-quantitative. During Alex Wright's workshop, I have also learned Kawakita Jiro analysis, a technique for groups with which people first silently jot down their ideas and observations to post-its and then these can be clustered and categorized to structure the analysis and make results emerge. What to do with the results next?

sec.title: Open research results (documentation, datasets and code)
sec.p: Reading Bruce Sterling's book Shaping Things felt really inspiring. Particularly how he illustrates his vision with his passionate story around a bottle of wine, gizmo wine. By the way, have you spotted the glass in the Mozilla UX Design Process? Published in 2005, a decade ago, some ideas feel not so futuristic anymore: the spime and the Internet of Things. He entroduces his book by calling for makers and designers of decent technologies, that are fully documented, trackable, searchable.

I strongly believe that publishing research results is a requirement for ensuring that ideas get traced, understood, iterated. I try to publish most source code related to my research results as much as I'm allowed to, and mostly on github. Doug Cook's project for a course in visualization at Berkeley from Fall 2014 shows in one visualization that Mozilla has been the organization owning the greatest amount of projects on github from May to September 2013. Mozilla UX team members publish their findings on their blog and in publications as overviewed before (CHI'09,CSCW'13).

sec.title: Fuel personal creativity remotely, collaborate creatively in person
sec.p: Creativity and flow require solitude or aloneness. I believe that offices are really necessary for organizations producing technologies when teams develop or use specific hardware, or need to collaborate together. Great, Mozilla teams seem to mostly work on software and use off-the-shelf hardware (let alone the recent work of Mozilla Factory). I also like that most positions can be acted remotely at Mozilla and that Mozilla offers a travel and conference budget including for meeting people for usability evaluations.

According to Bret Victor, technologists should invest their time and skills in addressing the issue of climate change. One partial solution seems to be reducing petroleum waste from transportation. The most polluting mode of transportation ranked in his article is personal passenger vehicles, way above flights. When the schedule calls for personal work, I find it better to fuel creativity by remote working alone than spoiling commuting time and energy. But real, physical, tangible human contact is necessary for collaborations, for better understanding people, and for evaluations with users.

sec.title: Future work
sec.p: The user experience researcher offer states: This role will be about 80% evaluative research and 20% generative research, similarly to The Pareto Principle. The following ideas for future work are ordered in an evaluative-to-generative dimension.

sec.title: Firefox workflow analysis
sec.p: I talked earlier about Alex Wright's two-dimensional rendering of a definition space for UX methods. Christian Rohrer from the Nielsen/Norman Group proposes a variant by adding a third dimension: the context of product use. This underlines one significant issue: into what extent do people that test products iterations actually use these products? How can we analyze the workflow of people beyond one product that we want to test?

Are there Mozilla UX projects addressing this issue? I could stumble upon Test Pilot which was an extension for Firefox allowing people to take part in studies and submit their data. Lots of test cases and findings were released until 2013 and 2014. The departure of its main developer seems to have stalled the project. Digging deeper brings us to the upcoming Idea Town, with a mockup splash nicely designed by John Gruen from Mozilla UX. I am eager to get to know more!

During the past semester I have been developing InspectorWidget, an opensource system to analyze users behaviors in their applications. InspectorWidget works on closed applications that do not provide source code nor scripting capabilities, but as well on opensource applications such as tools made by Mozilla. InspectorWidget covers the whole pipeline of software analysis from logging input events to visual statistics through browsing and programmable annotation. InspectorWidget allows post-recording logging, that is defining metrics of observation after recording and logging. InspectorWidget does not require programming skills. To achieve this, InspectorWidget combines low-level event logging (e.g. mouse and keyboard events) and high-level screen features (e.g. interface widgets) captured though computer vision techniques. I have started collaborations on it with researchers interested in how people deal with menus and shortcuts, among other GUI widgets and interaction techniques. We believe that InspectorWidget can benefit end users, usability experts and HCI researchers. The current prototype is almost on github.

sec.title: Browsing bookmarks and histories
sec.p: Last year I stumbled by chance upon the Mozilla Chronicle project. When I saw the figures on its tumblr, I was immediately attracted by the second Context and View Frequency of History Items. How many times have I lost track of bookmarks even if I kept a folder system with careful choices on breadth and depth! This left me wondering whether Chronicle would be a project centered on information visualization of browsing histories. During my PhD thesis I have produced a thorough state-of-the-art on the design space of media/file browsers illustrated with numerous examples. I also have undertaken user experiments regarding information visualization of media content, particularly how people appreciated browsing layouts of image-based representations relatively to their performance in browsing, leading to the design of the AudioMetro visualization. This use case sounds very similar to browsing a collection of bookmarks with thumbnails. I would be glad to help propose high-fidelity prototypes for exploring browsing history and evaluate these with people, part of the Chronicle project if it is to be resumed.

sec.title: MozVR and haptics
sec.p: The current research tracks of the MozVR team focus on the browsing experience using off-the-shelf virtual reality devices, currently the Oculus Rift for display. How can people interact in virtual reality? A companion off-the-shelf device, the Oculus Touch, is a split gamepad that two-handed users hold with their hands, one pad in each. While its description states that user movement sensing is precise, how do users receive feedback from their actions and behavior? From vibrators controlled with steady amplitude and frequency? Why the name Touch? A (research) friend expert in multimodal interfaces and I designed and prototyped the InfoPhys system towards reinstating a richer and fuller sense of touch to information visualization: tactile, proprioceptive and kinesthetic display. It builds upon an extension for Firefox for information visualization for textual analysis, Paper Machines, and a shift on web standards, from SVG to X3D. Instead of a person hidden in the box as in the Mechanical Turk, we placed a repurposed off-the-shelf haptic device inside, the Novint Falcon. But this device is too bulky, power consuming and rare (extinct) to reach a wide audience of users. This spring, HCI/UX researchers expert on phantom/haptic illusions perception and I are organizing the WebAudioHaptics tutorial at the Web Audio Conference (WAC) 2016, proposing two research tracks for solving these issues: prototyping the user interface relies on 1) a pair of low-cost vibrating devices of a smaller form factor, wearable, replicable with off-the-shelf components (hardware); and 2) on Web Audio technologies (software), making it directly designable and accessible from the browser. I believe this might be of interest for the MozVR team, whose members partly come from the Mozilla UX team.

sec.title: Closing
sec.p: Looking forward to working at Mozilla!

caption.title: Workflow of InspectorWidget
caption.p: InspectorWidget is an opensource system to analyze users behaviors in their applications. Its workflow: the experimenter records users' activity, then browses the recordings and programs annotations. InspectorWidget then automates annotations that the experimenter can analyze using the provided visualization tool, Data can be exported for processing in a different statistical analysis tool. Soon on github.

caption.p: InspectorWidget is an opensource system to analyze users behaviors in their applications. In the top right frame we see the playback of a screen recording of an application. In the top left frame we can visual program metrics to extract for behavioral analysis. On the bottom frame we can browse a timeline of events related to extracted metrics. Soon on github.

fig.label: Figure: AudioMetro by Christian Frisson et al.

caption.title: AudioMetro: evaluation content presentation layouts
caption.p: AudioMetro is an interactive visualization of sound collections. Sounds are represented by content-based glyphs, mapping perceptual sharpness (audio) to brightness and contour (visual). These glyphs are positioned in a starfield display using Student t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (tSNE) for dimension reduction, then a proximity grid optimized for preserving direct neighbors. Known-item search evaluation shows that our technique significantly outperforms a grid of sounds represented by dots and ordered by filename. Findings published.

fig.label: Figure: InfoPhys by Christian Frisson and Bruno Dumas

caption.p: Information visualization is the transformation of abstract data into visual, interactive representations. InfoPhys is a device that enables the direct, tangible manipulation of visualizations. InfoPhys makes use of a force-feedback pointing device to simulate haptic feedback while the user explores visualizations projected on top of the device. We present a use case illustrating the trends in ten years of TEI proceedings and how InfoPhys allows users to feel and manipulate these trends. Soon on github.

caption.title: WebAudioHaptics tutorial at Web Audio Conference (WAC) 2016 by Christian Frisson, Thomas Pietrzak, Siyan Zhao and Ali Israr
caption.p: The Web Audio Haptics WAC Tutorial 2016 will explore how to create meaningful haptic content that engages different areas of the body using off-the-shelf hardware and open source software running on a web browser using Web Audio technologies. The tutorial aims to teach participant an easy-to-use method to create dynamic haptic content as well as to give participants an understanding of apparent tactile illusions, a perception of illusory motion between two areas on the body, and apply this knowledge towards generating personalized haptic experiences. Tutorial soon on github. Picture courtesy of Disney Research.
